title: 106_s2748
content: The Act may be cited as the "Russian-American Trust and Cooperation Act of 2000". The Congress finds that the Russian Federation operates an intelligence facility at Lourdes, Cuba, leased for $100-300 million a year, which is used for intelligence activities against the United States. The facility is the largest operated by Russia outside the former Soviet Union. The Lourdes facility in Cuba is a large intelligence base operated by Russia outside the former Soviet Union. It covers a 28 square-mile area and employs over 1,500 Russian personnel. The base has multiple tracking dishes and a satellite system used for intercepting communications, including obtaining sensitive information about US military operations during Operation Desert Storm. The Lourdes facility in Cuba, operated by Russia, is used for collecting personal information about US citizens and engaging in cyberwarfare against the United States. The facility's operational significance increased after a directive from Russian President Boris Yeltsin in 1996 to gather US and Western economic secrets. The Russian Government spent over $3 billion on the operation and modernization of the Lourdes facility in Cuba. Former US officials confirmed the expansion and upgrade of the facility. In December 1999, a Russian military delegation visited Cuba to discuss the ongoing operation of the Lourdes facility. The text chunk discusses the prohibition on bilateral debt rescheduling and forgiveness for the Russian Federation. The President is prohibited from rescheduling or forgiving any bilateral debt owed by the Russian Federation until they close the intelligence facility at Lourdes, Cuba. The President can waive this prohibition with a 10-day notice. The President can waive the prohibition on rescheduling or forgiving Russian debt owed until they close the intelligence facility at Lourdes, Cuba, with a 10-day notice to the relevant committees. The waiver must be certified in writing with detailed facts supporting the decision, and may be submitted in classified form if deemed appropriate. The President must provide periodic reports every 180 days to the House and Senate committees on the extent to which certain requirements are being met. SEC. 4. REPORT ON THE CLOSING OF THE INTELLIGENCE FACILITY AT LOURDES, CUBA. The President must submit a report every 120 days detailing Russia's actions to close the intelligence facility in Cuba and efforts by US agencies to verify these actions.
